Award.AwardTitle: Measuring Cosmic Magnetism with the Low Frequency Radio Array
Award.AbstractNarration:
Part 1
This proposal plans to carry out low-frequency radio measurements of cosmic magnetism through a collaboration between Arizona State University and the German Long Wavelength Consortium. Each year, the program will fund two first-year graduate students and five advanced undergraduates, who will carry out research with the Low Frequency Array (LOFAR), a remarkable new European radio telescope. Due to its sensitivity, resolution, and frequency coverage, LOFAR will allow for intergalactic magnetic field measurements orders of magnitude better than previously possible.

Part 2
Magnetic fields thread the Universe, setting the criteria for star formation in galaxies, controlling the evolution of galaxy clusters, and altering the intergalactic medium from which all galaxies formed. Yet very little is known about their properties.
LOFAR is the first of a new generation of telescopes that operates in the extremely low frequency range between 10 and 240 MHz. Magnetic fields are primarily detected by their interactions with cosmic rays, and only telescopes at these low frequencies, which
correspond to low cosmic ray energies, are able to make sensitive measurements far away from cosmic ray sources and out in the depths of intergalactic space. With this remarkable new tool, the projects carried out by IRES students will help to open a new window on the magnetic universe. On galaxy scales, they will probe the connection between star formation and magnetism and the origin of the magnetic fields that surround galaxies. On galaxy cluster scales, they will probe the unknown physics of the hot
intracluster medium and the evolution of the synchrotron emitting bubbles found within it. On cosmic scales they will uncover the magnetic properties of the web of gas that connects all galaxies. Together they will be filling in a key piece of the fundamental question: what is the structure of the Universe on the largest scales?

POR.DRECONTENT:
This International Research Experience for Students (IRES)  grant enabled fourteen undergraduate and graduate students to carry out research projects using the Low Frequency Array (LOFAR), a remarkable European radio telescope. LOFAR is the first of a new generation of extremely low frequency radio telescopes that operate between 10 and 240 MHz, making use of advanced computer technology and analysis methods. Due to its sensitivity, resolution, and frequency coverage, LOFAR is opening a new window on the universe. Through this IRES program, the students participated in research projects focused on applying the telescope array to make forefront measurements of magnetic fields on galactic and intergalactic scales. 

The activity took place yearly and consisted of three stages: (i) a weekly seminar taught during which the students learned the basics of radio telescopes, cosmic magnetism, and the LOFAR instrument; (ii) a seven-week visit to Hamburg, Germany, during which they worked with LOFAR scientists on research projects tailored to their strengths and interests; (iii) completion of the projects in Arizona under the guidance of myself and several other faculty members. Finally, each student wrote up their research in the style of a journal paper and made presentations of their results to both students and the general public.

The intellectual merit of these results was extremely high, and several students continued to their research work to produce papers published in refereed journals, including forefront studies of star-formation, cosmic-ray propagation, and the impact of magnetic fields on galaxy outflows. 

The broader impact of the work included: (i) communicating the work to the general public through student presentations as well as an interactive exhibit at the yearly open house hosted by our department;  (ii) training three graduate students, all of whom leveraged the skills and collaborations they built as part of the program to complete their dissertation work; (iii) training eleven undergraduate students, many of whom are now at top graduate programs across the country.
